instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> i found the short on <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> when removed short is gone what is <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and where can i get it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You've probably have short to ground on L9580/81 too.
That suppose dead NAND chip (at least one).
Check the actual diode mode to ground there, after removing <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i replace <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> now i have 19.4v 0.02 A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: there is no short on L9580/81

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Compare diode mode to ground readings between L9080/580.

Try to put it now in DFU.
Be sure to use 96/140W charger.
